task.title: Writing standards on a structured way
task.shortdesc: Structure can mean the assembly of documents from small building blocks called "topics", and also a consistent internal structure using a text mark-up language.

section.title: Mark up separates meaning from presentation
section.p: As well as writing in mark up (where the effects of the mark up might not be very apparent), you will also have little direct control of the appearance of the output. This includes important aspects line page breaks and the appearance of tables.

It can be difficult to adjust to this, particulary when you are used to having easy control of document presentation with a word processor, and especially when the output is less satisfactory than you can acheive with one.
Nevertheless, after time, it does become much simpler to just open a map and start work without being bothered by page layout, margins, and font size.

In DITA, there is still some presentational structure to consider. Italics and bold are there, and images need to be given a (e.g width) size for PDF output (or they can spill over the page). It's still much, much less than you will find with a word processor.

Nevertheless, It's easy to emphasise how you or your writers will spend less time worrying about structure and more time worrying about appearance. In fact, DITA users are very interested in the appearance of their documents.

You can have some direct control of the appearance of XHTML output (and by extention EPUB and oXygen's WebHelp by configuring the appearance with cascading style sheets (CSS). CSS provides a template-like way of altering the appearance. It's fairly easy to learn the basics (the web is not short of CSS tutorials) and it's well integrated woth DITA and oXygen.

PDF output is much, much harder to customise. You can add some images to flag up parts of text in conditional processing, but that's about it for the DITA-OT unless you are or can call upon the skills of a developer.
Large Word documents are unwieldly, inconsistent, and tend to die after 50 pages.
A real problem with Word documents is that they just don't scale. There's many way to achieve the same thing.

section.title: Authors can use different Word template and can have different styles
Authors manage sequential numbering as well as the content and appearance
Structural writing means the computer takes some of the strain
Write upward from small parts rather than divide downwards
section.p: A document written from the bottom up can look similar to a document split into sections and subsections ("clauses" and "subclauses" in standards), but they are quite different regarding their maintainabilty and (less visibly but not less true), sometimes their ability to be understood by their reader.
